elements.content: This is a normal paragraph ( element). To add some length to it, let us mention that this page was primarily written for testing the effect of . You can use it for various other purposes as well, like just checking how your browser displays various HTML elements.

This is another paragraph. I think it needs to be added that the set of elements tested is not exhaustive in any sense. I have selected those elements for which it can make sense to write user style sheet rules, in my opionion.
This is a element. Authors may use such elements instead of paragraph markup for various reasons. (End of .)

This is a block quotation containing a single paragraph. Well, not quite, since this is not quoted text, but I hope you understand the point. After all, this page does not use HTML markup very normally anyway.
The following contains address information about the author, in an element.

This is a paragraph before an list (). Note that the spacing between a paragraph and a list before or after that is hard to tune in a user style sheet. You can't guess which paragraphs are logically related to a list, e.g. as a "list header".
Four. This is the last item in this list. Let us terminate the list now without making any more fuss about it.
Three. Well, probably this list item should be longer so that it will probably wrap to the next line in rendering.
Three. Well, probably this list item should be longer so that it will probably wrap to the next line in rendering.

This is a paragraph before a list (). Note that the spacing between a paragraph and a list before or after that is hard to tune in a user style sheet. You can't guess which paragraphs are logically related to a list, e.g. as a "list header".

Three. Well, probably this list item should be longer. Note that if items are short, lists look better if they are compactly presented, whereas for long items, it would be better to have more vertical spacing between items.
Four. This is the last item in this list. Let us terminate the list now without making any more fuss about it.

This is a paragraph before a list (). In principle, such a list should consist of and associated definitions. But many authors use elements for fancy "layout" things. Usually the effect is not bad, if you design user style sheet rules for which are suitable for real definition lists.
( markup used - just bolding with unspecified semantics)
here we have some text ( markup used)
an is an entity consisting of eight bits ( markup used for the term being defined)
this is simple ( markup used for emphasizing a word)
here we have some text ( markup used)
type when prompted for an answer ( markup used for text indicating keyboard input)
He said: (a quotation inside a quotation)
you may get the message at times ( markup used for sample output)
( markup used; note: is a nonstandard synonym for )

In order to test how subscripts and superscripts ( and markup) work inside running text, we need some dummy text around constructs like x and HO (where subscripts occur). So here is some fill so that you will (hopefully) see whether and how badly the subscripts and superscripts mess up vertical spacing between lines. Now superscripts: M, 1, and then some mathematical notations: e, sin , and some nested superscripts (exponents) too: e and f(x) (where 2 and a+b+c should appear as exponents of exponents).
the command displays the file specified by the ( markup used to indicate a word as a variable).
Some of the elements tested above are typically displayed in a monospace font, often using the presentation for all of them. This tests whether that is the case on your browser:
This is sample text inside code markup

This is a text paragraph that contains some inline links. Generally, inline links (as opposite to e.g. links lists) are problematic from the perspective, but they may have use as “incidental”, less relevant links. See the document .
This is a form containing various fields (with some initial values (defaults) set, so that you can see how input text looks like without actually typing it):
The following two radio buttons are inside a element with a :
The following table has a caption. The first row and the first column contain table header cells ( elements) only; other cells are data cells ( elements), with attributes:
